PostValue.explanation: This is an event/program announcement for a niche 12‑week fellowship at the intersection of AI and animal welfare. It could be moderately useful to EA community members working on animal advocacy, career development, or AI-for-good projects (networking, skills, small-scale project outputs), but it is not foundational to EA or AI safety and would not substantially change major priorities or worldviews. For humanity at large it is trivial: limited scale and contingent impact even if the fellowship succeeds.

PostRobustness.actionable_feedback:
1) Provide key logistical and eligibility details up front (these are the first questions applicants and EA readers will have). Say explicitly: cohort size, application link, application materials required, selection criteria/timeline (when applicants will be notified), whether there is a fee or stipend, whether the program is online or in-person and what time zones/schedules are expected, and whether you offer accessibility support. Action: add a short “Practical details” box with these facts so readers can immediately judge fit.

2) Bolster credibility and expected impact with concrete evidence and outcomes. EA readers will want to know why this is worth their time: list confirmed mentors (names & affiliations) or at least types of mentors, funders/organisers, any prior run results or pilot outputs (projects, papers, jobs), and the measurable outputs you expect from each participant (e.g., project deliverable templates, publication/advocacy targets, post-fellowship support). If you don’t have past results, be explicit about that and explain how you’ll evaluate success. Action: add a one-paragraph “Why this fellowship matters” with 2–3 specific examples or metrics.

3) Clarify scope, potential conflicts and data/privacy concerns around tools. You mention ChatNGO and project work — say what data/privacy safeguards are in place, whether participants or project outputs may be shared publicly, and whether using ChatNGO creates IP/ownership or reuse constraints. Also clarify what you mean by “No technical knowledge needed” versus the expected skills/background of competitive applicants (e.g., ideal mix of policy/advocacy/technical backgrounds). Action: add a short FAQ covering tool usage, IP/data policies, and the ideal applicant profile.

Implementing these three fixes should make the post far more actionable and trustworthy to EA Forum readers while keeping length compact.
PostRobustness.improvement_potential: This feedback targets the post’s biggest practical weaknesses: missing logistical/eligibility details, lack of credibility signals, and unanswered data/IP questions that would make EA readers hesitate to apply. Implementing these three concise changes would substantially increase the post’s usefulness and trustworthiness without bloating it. (Minor caveat: asking for confirmed mentor names may be infeasible if not yet finalized, but the feedback already allows for listing types or noting pilots.)

PostAuthorAura.explanation: I could not find evidence that 'Jay Luong' is a known figure in the Effective Altruism/rationalist ecosystem (no notable posts, talks, or leadership roles on core EA/rationalist platforms). Similarly, there is no indication of broad public or academic fame — appears to be at best a minor/obscure online presence or a pseudonym. If you can provide links or context (articles, handles), I can reassess.

PostClarity.explanation: The post is clear, well-structured and easy to understand: it states the fellowship's purpose, timeline, weekly format, time commitment, project component, mentorship, tools, and the application deadline. The call to action is obvious and the week-by-week program is concise. Weaknesses are minor formatting/repetition (image/"Apply now" repeated, inconsistent use of ampersands), and it omits some practical details a reader might expect (eligibility, cost/fees, selection process, timezone/logistics). Fixing those and tightening a couple of repetitions would push this toward a 9–10.

PostNovelty.explanation: For EA Forum readers this is largely not novel: it’s a program announcement about a fellowship at the already-discussed AI ↔ animal-welfare intersection (AI safety/longtermist and animal advocacy communities have explored these themes and run similar trainings). The most original element is the specific program design (12-week structure, mentorship, use of ChatNGO) rather than new conceptual claims. For the general public the idea is moderately novel — many people know of AI and animal welfare separately, but a targeted fellowship focusing on AI tools for animal advocacy, decoding animal communication, and precision livestock farming will be new or surprising to a fair number of educated readers.

PostInferentialSupport.explanation: This post is primarily a program announcement rather than an argumentative piece. Strengths: the argument (that the fellowship will introduce and support people working at the AI+animal-welfare frontier) is clear and the curriculum, schedule, and resources (mentorship, ChatNGO access) are plausibly relevant. Weaknesses: there is little substantive reasoning about why the program will be effective (no theory of change, selection criteria, or comparisons to alternatives) and almost no empirical evidence (no prior cohort outcomes, impact metrics, instructor/mentor credentials, or evaluation plans). As a result the claim that the fellowship will accelerate careers and produce concrete contributions is weakly supported.

PostExternalValidation.validation_notes: Most major factual claims in the post are well supported by primary sources: Electric Sheep (the organiser) publicly describes the 12‑week Futurekind program, its learning/project blocks, session format, no‑coding requirement, and that participants will have access to ChatNGO; the EA Forum post and related announcements give the April 1 application deadline and tentative May start. Independent sources confirm ChatNGO exists as an NGO‑focused AI platform. Minor uncertainties: (a) small inconsistency in the published end date (the EA post says May 1–July 31, 2025; an aggregator lists May 1–July 24, 2025) and (b) I did not find a separate public announcement on the Stray Dog Institute website explicitly repeating that it is providing ChatNGO to Electric Sheep (Electric Sheep’s site states the provision). Overall, primary documentation from Electric Sheep + the EA Forum announcement validate most claims; a couple of small details (exact end date and an independent Stray Dog confirmation) are not independently corroborated on other pages I found.
sources: EA Forum post: 'Last week to apply for the Futurekind AI Fellowship! (deadline: April 1)' — Jay Luong (EA Forum).
Electric Sheep — Futurekind program page ('Futurekind | Learn AI for Planet Impact — Electric Sheep').
Electric Sheep — About / Teachable pages describing Futurekind (Electric Sheep Teachable / About pages).
EA Forum post: 'Apply to become a Futurekind AI Facilitator or Mentor (deadline: April 10)' — confirms related deadlines and timeline.
